content.subtitle: 7 reasons to be excited about deployment

paragraphs.text: By Alejandro Escamilla / via unsplash.com

paragraphs.name: title
paragraphs.text: Capistrano Version 3

paragraphs.name: subtitle
paragraphs.text: 7 reasons to be excited about deployment

paragraphs.name: 7b17
paragraphs.text: Deploying — the smell of coffee, the satisfaction of shipping, the excitement of lovingly crafted code going out into the world. It’s hard not to love releasing code, but when it comes to actually writing deployment scripts, it’s one part of programming that most people don’t write home about.

paragraphs.name: c719
paragraphs.text: In the Ruby world, Capistrano has been the de-facto standard for deploying applications since it’s release in 2006, but the familiar syntax and bundled deploy tasks have remained largely constant since Jamis Buck’s departure in 2009. This summer however, it’s time to get excited about deployment again — Capistrano’s core team have been hard at work and version three is on the edge of a beta release. All in all, this feels like the perfect time to share some of the features about which I’m most excited.
All New, All the Time

paragraphs.name: d613
paragraphs.text: Make no mistake, this is a ground-up rewrite. Capistrano is now a lean, focused and lightweight deployment management tool, cloc’ing in at just 700 lines of code. Capistrano’s Rake-like DSL has been replaced with Rake itself, while behind the scenes SSHKit — a new gem which fell naturally out of the development process — provides the heavy lifting. This combination gives us a new, yet familiar, powerful and expressive DSL:

paragraphs.name: e95e
paragraphs.text:
desc ‘Example task’
  task :migrate do

paragraphs.name: 02c7
paragraphs.text:
on primary :db do
      within release_path do
        with rails_env: fetch(:stage) do
          execute :rake, “db:migrate”
        end
      end
    end

paragraphs.name: 85ce
paragraphs.text: end

paragraphs.name: ee53
paragraphs.text: Along with the core of Capistrano, the bundled deployment tasks have been re-created with a more contemporary toolchain in mind. Framework specific tasks have been broken out into separate gems, whilst the new `before` and `after` syntax makes it simple for gems to hook into any task:
after :finishing, :notify

paragraphs.name: d4b9
paragraphs.text: This includes `cap install`:

paragraphs.name: 2f2f
paragraphs.text:
after :install, :create_a_directory do
  mkdir_p ‘my_custom_directory’
end

paragraphs.name: ca2e
paragraphs.text: And also the stage configuration tasks, for example `cap production`:

before :production, :warn do
  info ‘Deploying to production, hold tight!’
end

paragraphs.name: a46a
paragraphs.text: Multistage by default
From the initial install, Capistrano encourages thinking in terms of ‘stages’, the environments to which we will deploy our applications.

paragraphs.name: 581a
paragraphs.text: We can optionally specify the required stages as part of the installation task.

paragraphs.name: fc78
paragraphs.text: $ cap install STAGES=sandbox,qa,production

paragraphs.name: 347e
paragraphs.text: This creates all that is needed to get started. These files include minimal configuration and are full of comments and examples.

paragraphs.name: 0de1
paragraphs.text:
├── Capfile
├── config
│   ├── deploy
│   │   ├── production.rb
│   │   ├── qa.rb
│   │   └── sandbox.rb
│   └── deploy.rb
└── lib
 └── capistrano
   └── tasks

paragraphs.name: e7b2
paragraphs.text: The generated ‘Capfile’ takes care of loading the bundled deploy tasks as well as any custom tasks from `lib/capistrano/tasks`

paragraphs.name: b11c
paragraphs.text:
# Load DSL and stages
require ‘capistrano/setup’

paragraphs.name: 438a
paragraphs.text:
# Include default deployment tasks
require ‘capistrano/deploy’

paragraphs.name: cf2e
paragraphs.text:
# Loads custom tasks from `lib/capistrano/tasks’
Dir.glob(‘lib/capistrano/tasks/*.cap’).each { |r| import r }

paragraphs.name: f12f
paragraphs.text: And for those who dislike the naming convention, it’s worth noting that both `capfile` and `capfile.rb` will also work.

paragraphs.name: f2ad
paragraphs.text: Configuration that applies to all stages can be set in `config/deploy.rb`:

paragraphs.name: 5ff6
paragraphs.text:
set :application, ‘my app name’
set :repo_url, ‘git@example.com:me/my_repo.git’

paragraphs.name: e76f
paragraphs.text: Stage specific configuration is set in the corresponding stage file:

paragraphs.name: fb41
paragraphs.text: The `server` syntax is also available where a single server has multiple roles:

paragraphs.name: 22d4
paragraphs.text:
set :stage, :sandbox
 server ‘example.com’, user: ‘deploy’, roles: %w{web app db}

paragraphs.name: 5e54
paragraphs.text: A list of default tasks is available by running `cap -vT`

paragraphs.name: 92a4
paragraphs.text: Hot is the New Cold

The core Capistrano deploy tasks are idempotent, so whilst the setup tasks can be run individually, there’s really no need. `cap deploy:cold` is no more. Capistrano will setup the folder structure, including any specific directories, as part of the pre-deployment checks when running `cap production deploy`

paragraphs.name: d3ef
paragraphs.text:
.
├── current -> /var/www/cap-test/releases/20130807201118
├── releases
│ ├── 20130807200904
│ ├── 20130807201054
│ └── 20130807201118
├── repo
│ ├── FETCH_HEAD
│ ├── HEAD
│ ├── branches
│ ├── config
│ ├── description
│ ├── hooks
│ ├── info
│ ├── objects
│ ├── packed-refs
│ └── refs
├── revisions.log
└── shared
 ├── bin
 ├── bundle
 ├── config
 ├── log
 ├── public
 ├── tmp
 └── vendor
If upgrading an existing deploy, an early version of the upgrade guide is available.

paragraphs.name: e2e5
paragraphs.text: Dry Runnings

paragraphs.name: 4bc7
paragraphs.text: Visually confirm every command to be run without ever touching a server:

paragraphs.name: 17cb
paragraphs.text: cap production deploy —dry-run

paragraphs.name: 65cb
paragraphs.text: Rolling Restarts

paragraphs.name: 275d
paragraphs.text: Commands can be executed in parallel, sequence or in groups.

paragraphs.name: 2e03
paragraphs.text:
on roles :app, in: :sequence, wait: 2 do
  execute :touch, ‘tmp/restart.txt’
end

paragraphs.name: cbd6
paragraphs.text: Log Levels and Formatters

paragraphs.name: 7c7f
paragraphs.text: If one word could describe Capistrano, that word could very well be “verbose”. With this release, we can finally get unwieldy logs under control with both log level and formatting options.

paragraphs.name: e495
paragraphs.text:
set :format, :pretty
set :log_level, :info

paragraphs.name: 1b04
paragraphs.text: Formatters are very simple to implement, personally I look forward to my first Nyan Cat deploy.

paragraphs.name: fe3d
paragraphs.text: Ask — don’t tell

paragraphs.name: 04e5
paragraphs.text: Keep variables variable by asking for values at run-time:

paragraphs.name: 42f8
paragraphs.text: ask :branch, ‘my_default_branch’
When the variable `:branch` is first requested, we will see a Highline-inspired prompt requesting the value. Just hitting return will select the default value shown between pipes:

paragraphs.name: ef3c
paragraphs.text: Please enter branch: |my_default_branch|

paragraphs.name: a0f1
paragraphs.text: The default can also be a little more practical:

paragraphs.name: db42
paragraphs.text: ask :branch, proc { `git rev-parse —abbrev-ref HEAD`.chomp }

paragraphs.name: 895b
paragraphs.text: Please enter branch: |feature/cap-test|

paragraphs.name: fc51
paragraphs.text: Excited yet? The beta release is imminent, for an excellent place to get started right now try the ‘Getting Started’ walk-through. And if you’ve enjoyed this, feel free to check out my more usual blogging home, or find me on Twitter.

paragraphs.name: 8e61
paragraphs.text: Update — 3.0.0 has now been officially released.
